commentBody:
Re: "Dogs are a big deal in this part of Punjab, about 20 miles from the border with Pakistan."

What about this?: Dogs are a big deal in this part of Punjab, about 30 kilometers (about 20 miles) from the border with Pakistan.

Too often The Times writes as if countries outside of the U.S. also use inch-pound units regularly when in fact the U.S. is just about the only country left in the world that does. In a nutshell, SI (commonly "the metric system") is the only true common language in the world, sort of an example of Esperanto gone right!

replies.commentBody: Legally recognized is not the same as adopted.  SI is fine for science and engineering, but customary units are much more practical for everyday use, which is why we (and in many cases, the Brits) continue to use them, and why a paper of record in the U.S. uses them.

You could have made this same comment, say, 40 years ago, when perhaps a large number of countries were still primarily using inch-pound units. But now? Apparently all but a few countries find SI fine for everyday practical use.

Since Mr. Corbett's essay here is titled "Tangled Passages", that is something that describes inch-pound system well, with their silly tangled connections for units of length and units of weight.

SI, the metric system? One unit for length (meter) and one unit for mass (kilogram).

A good example is the case of Australia. In 1970, it was entirely an inch-pound nation. In 1980, it was a metric one.

In a nutshell, many Americans cling to the familiar, whether good or bad, whereas the peoples of other nations apparently know better than US.
OK, if the metric system is so wonderful, why isn't there metric time?  Also, in the matter of temperature, what is the value of going to a less precise system of measurement?
